newsitem.title: FINLAND: FOCUS-UPM-Kymmene cautious as Q1 dips.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-UPM-Kymmene cautious as Q1 dips.

text.p: Europe's largest forestry group UPM-Kymmene Oy on Thursday reported a dip in first-quarter profits in line with market expectations, but voiced a more cautious view on full-year prospects than some rivals.
Profit before extraordinary items and tax fell two percent to 1.35 billion markka ($264 million) from 1.37 billion in the year-ago period -- a less sharp fall than reported by some of its rivals.
UPM said it expected 1997 earnings to be about the same as 1996, when it made a profit before extras and tax of 3.6 billion markka and operating profit of 5.6 billion.
That view contrasted with an expected improvement in full-year earnings from Finland's Metsa-Serla and a generally upbeat market view from Sweden's AssiDoman, which both reported earlier this week.
CEO Juha Niemela said he saw a good possibility for better 1997 earnings: the official forecast was on the cautious side.

Asked about chances for a boost to the company's earnings, he said: "There is a good possibility for that as well. But to be on the cautious side we see that we will reach about the same level as we did last year.
"Surprises to the negative side are also possible, but not as likely as they are to the opposite direction," he told Reuters Financial Television in an interview.

UPM's net sales in Q1 dipped to 13.09 billion markka from 13.27 billion in the year-ago period. Its caution came amid sustained uncertainty on prospects for pulp and paper markets, with pulp price hikes only recently starting to look solid.

Analysts' median forecast for UPM-Kymmene's Q1 profit had been 1.35 billion markka in a 952 million to 1.58 billion range: its stock was off 0.50 markka at 122.00 in a muted response to the report in late Helsinki trade.
Overall, UPM-Kymmene said strong economic growth in Europe would underpin an increase in paper consumption, but it voiced fears of overcapacity in fine paper in the second half.
"Sales prices for printing and writing papers are expected to rise, although only marginally during the first half of the year," the company said.
In fine paper, it said European production capacity threatened to rise faster than demand in the second half.

"Market pulp prices probably bottomed out in April," UPM-Kymmene said: Niemela told a news conference that there was "strong faith" in markets that recently announced long-fibre price hikes to $580 per tonne from $520 per tonne would hold.

"I would expect $580 to become the sales price sometime in the summer, at the latest by early autumn," Niemela said, adding that $580 was already the market price in the United States. Pulp prices have traditionally been a compass for paper grades.
On newsprint, UPM-Kymmene said European prices were expected to benefit later this year from a rise in consumption and prices which had started in North America.
But while some analysts agreed, others saw more stability -- continuing the broad uncertainty which has been a hallmark of pulp and paper markets in recent months.
